posts.author: CriticalMiss
posts.content:
I've been thinking about subclass lately and wanted to get everyone's opinions.

Quick question about subclass that came up in our game last night.

I'd love to hear everyone's experiences with subclass and how it's worked in your games.

What do you all think? Has anyone else had similar questions about subclass?

posts.author: RogueReroll
posts.content:
I've been playing a Elf Druid in my campaign, and I've noticed that Cleric really impacts how effective the character is in combat.

How do other DMs balance encounters that involve Cleric? I find it either makes combats too easy or too difficult.

We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use Cleric to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!

In my campaign, we had a situation with Cleric that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.

posts.author: InitiativeTracker
posts.content:
The way I understand the rules for discussion, it should work like this: when you take the action, you need to roll ability checks to determine the outcome.

I think the RAW (Rules As Written) for discussion are clear, but many DMs seem to interpret it differently.

My DM interprets discussion differently than the rules as written. How do you all handle this at your tables?

posts.author: SorcerousSally
posts.content:
I've been playing a Human Paladin in my campaign, and I've noticed that Cleric really impacts how effective the character is in combat.

Looking at page 127 of the Player's Handbook, it states that Cleric functions based on your proficiency bonus and ability modifiers.

In the new 2024 rules update, they changed how Cleric works. Now it's more streamlined but I'm not sure if it's better overall.

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about Cleric. Based on my experience, it works differently.
